Award.AwardTitle: Mechanics of Multiferroic Composites for Strong Magnetoelectric Coupling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to seek the strongest possible magnetoelectric coupling through the route of multiferroic composites that consist of a ferroelectric and a ferromagnetic phase. This idea grew out of the realization that single-phase multiferroic materials are rare, and among the existing ones their magnetoelectric coupling is generally weak. On the other hand a multiferroic composite could deliver strong magneto-electric interactions through their commonly shared mechanical characteristics. In this research, we will explore the maximum potential through a combination of micromechanics and phase-field approaches for both bulk and nanostructured multiferroic composites. We will apply the developed composite models to tune their volume concentrations, phase connectivity, and property contrast, to achieve this goal. The overall polarization of the composite under an external magnetic field, and its overall magnetization under an external electric field, will be determined to assess the magnetoelectric coupling. In this process the evolution of ferroelectric and magnetic domains will also be uncovered. We intend to consider BaTiO3-CoFe2O4 composites in great details, with the 1-3, 2-2, 0-3, and 3-3 connectivity for the bulk, and 1-3 and 2-2 for nanostructured thin films. In this way the maximum magnetoelectric coupling for each connectivity pattern, and for all patterns, can be quantified.

Multiferroic materials with strong magnetoelectric coupling have a wide range of applications that require the exchange and interaction of mechanical, electrical, and magnetic energies. In information storage, for instance, coupling allows the data to be written electronically and read magnetically, thus avoiding the need to create a high local magnetic field to write. This class of materials is also widely known to be useful as actuators, sensors, transducers, and high-frequency devices whose properties need to be tuned electrically or magnetically. In microelectronics, the on-chip integration also demands the use of many nano-scaled multiferroics. This work will have direct impact to the development of new high-end devices. We intend to use this opportunity to educate some high school and undergraduate and graduate students. The PI will establish a summer program with TARGET (The Academy at Rutgers for Girls in Engineering and Technology) to increase their awareness. He will enlist the motivated undergraduates to join the Honor J.J. Slade Scholar Program (which requires a thesis), and provide multidiscipline training to the graduate students with a new course, Mechanics of Multiferroic Materials, and a weekly seminar. Minority, women, and economically underprivileged students will be actively recruited. The results will be made open to the public through publications, lectures, and a website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF project was concerned with the creation of strongest possible magnetoelectric coupling in materials. The major focus was on the generated magnitude of coupling coefficients in multiferroic composites that consist of a ferroelectric phase and a ferromagnetic phase. This idea was motivated by the fact that single-phase multiferroic materials are rare, and among the existing ones their magnetoelectric coupling is generally weak. On the other hand a multiferroic composite could deliver strong magnetoelectric interaction through judicious combinations of such two types of materials, such as barium titanate (BaTiO3, or BTO) which is ferroelectric and has strong electric-mechanical coupling and cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4, or CFO) which is ferromagnetic and has strong magnetic-mechanical coupling. However, neither BTO nor CFO possess magnetic-electric coupling, but when put together to form a composite material, magnetoelectric coupling could be generated through their commonly shared mechanical response.

There are many ways to put the two phases together through the commonly called phase connectivity. But broadly speaking, the three ways – called 0-3, 1-3, and 2-2 connectivities - are the most common ones. The 0-3 connectivity refers to the class of composite in which one phase is not exposed to the outside environment and the other is fully exposed, such as particle-reinforced composites. The 1-3 connectivity refers to the class in which only one direction is exposed to the outside in one phase while in the other phase all 3 directions are exposed, such as unidirectional aligned fiber composites. On the other hand the 2-2 connectivity refers to the class in which both phases have two directions totally exposed to the outside environment, such as multilayered structures. There are several components of magnetoelectric coupling coefficients, but the most important ones are alpha_33 and alpha_11, referring to the magnitude of magnetic induction under a unit electric field in the 3-direction (or vice versa), and in the 1-direction, respectively. Here direction-3 is along the aligned direction while direction-1 is perpendicular to it. These three connectivities are also the limiting cases of a two-phase composite in which one phase exists as aligned spheroidal inclusions with a given aspect ratio (length-to-diameter ratio) and the other as the matrix material in which inclusions are embedded. When the aspect ratio is equal to 1, it generates a 0-3 connectivity, and when it approaches infinity, or zero, it leads to the 1-3 or 2-2 connectivity, respectively.  

In this project, we have developed a micromechanics theory to calculate these coupling coefficients for all aspect ratios (from zero to infinity) and all volume concentrations (from 0 to 1) of inclusions. Thus all three types of connectivities have been fully explored. In addition, the considered composites include both CFO-in-BTO and BTO-in-CFO, which means that the ferromagnetic phase, CFO, is embedded inside the ferroelectric phase, BTO, or vice versa.  We have uncovered remarkable difference in the generated magnetoelectric coupling coefficients alpha_33 and alpha_11, as the microstructure changes from multilayers to the particle and the fiber cases. For instance, with the CFO-in-BTO configuration, the generated alpha_33 increases markedly as the aspect ratio of inclusions changes from 0 (the 2-2 or multilayered structure), to 1 (the 0-3 or particle-reinforced composite), and to infinity (the 1-3 or fiber-reinforced composite). The maximum alpha_33 is 30 x10^(-10) C/(A.m), which is generated in the 1-3 connectivity at the CFO volume concentration of about 0.55. For the generated alpha_11, the trends are exactly reversed. The maximum alpha_11 is -350 x10^(-10) C/(A.m), which is negative and is generated in the 2-2 connectivity with multilayered structure, at the volume concentration of 0.5.

The technical significance of this project lies in its potential applications to the electronic industry. Multiferroic materials with strong magnetoelectric coupling have a wide range of applications that require the exchange and interaction of mechanical, electrical, and magnetic energies. In information storage, for instance, coupling allows the data to be written electronically and read magnetically, thus avoiding the need to create a high local magnetic field to write. This class of materials is widely known to be useful as actuators, sensors, transducers, and high-frequency devices whose properties need to be tuned electrically or magnetically. In microelectronics, the on-chip integration also demands the use of many nano-scaled multiferroics. This work will have direct impact to the development of high-end electronic devices.

We have also used this opportunity to train the undergraduate and graduate students at Rutgers on the multidiscipline issue of magneto-electro-mechanical coupling of multiferroic composites. This subject is new to most students. Along the way they have become better prepared for their future challenges, and more ready to make contributions to this important field. Through lectures, and journal and book publications, we have also made the obtained results available to the open public.
